entries.english: I drank tea and ate bread
entries.context: Recent past tense - describing actions that just happened (moments ago)
entries.cultural_notes: Common everyday expressions for recent actions. Note the use of 'na' (and) to connect actions.

examples.english: I brought food to the table

grammatical_info.infinitives: kũnyua (to drink), kũrĩa (to eat), kũheha (to bring)

entries.english: I drank tea and ate bread
entries.context: Past tense - describing actions from early this morning
entries.cultural_notes: Note the different past tense marker compared to 'moments ago' - this indicates earlier in the day. Shows temporal distinction in Kikuyu verb conjugations.

examples.english: I brought food to the table

grammatical_info.comparison: Recent past uses 'nda-' prefix, morning past uses '-ire' ending
grammatical_info.infinitives: kũnyua (to drink), kũrĩa (to eat), kũheha (to bring)

entries.english: I woke up ten minutes ago
entries.context: Recent past tense - extended examples with more verbs
entries.cultural_notes: Demonstrates common morning routine vocabulary with past tense conjugations

examples.english: I took a bath with cold water
I put on my clothes quickly

examples.kikuyu: Ndaruga ũcũrũ wa mũtũ wa mũhĩa

examples.english: Then I shut the door and left

entries.english: To light - I lit - I lit earlier today
entries.context: Special conjugation pattern for verbs that start with vowels
entries.cultural_notes: Important grammatical pattern showing how vowel-initial verbs conjugate differently in past tenses

entries.context: Complete paradigm of first person singular and plural present progressive tense
entries.cultural_notes: Week 1-3 lesson material. Foundation for understanding Kikuyu verb conjugation system

entries.english: The future time (tomorrow or any future time)
entries.context: Complete paradigm of future tense for all six persons (I, you, he/she, they, we, you-plural)
entries.cultural_notes: Future tense can refer to tomorrow or even next year - context determines the timeframe

examples.english: I will wake up ten minutes later
you will wake up after ten minutes
he/she will bathe with cold water

grammatical_info.subject_markers: ngo- (1sg), ûgo- (2sg), age- (3sg), tûka- (1pl), mûka- (2pl), maka- (3pl)

entries.english: Second person future tense - today vs tomorrow/beyond
examples: Ûgwîthamba na maî mahoro (You will bathe with cold water today)
Ûgethamba na maî mahoro (You will bathe with cold water tomorrow)

entries.english: First person future tense - tomorrow and beyond
examples: Ngethamba na maî mahoro (I will bathe with cold water)
Ngahinga mûrango (I will shut/lock the door)
Rûcîû ngokîra dagîka ikûmi ciathira (Tomorrow I will wake up ten minutes later)

entries.english: First person future tense - moments later or anytime today
examples: Ngwîhumba nguo naihenya (I will put on clothes quickly)
Ngûrûga ûcûrû wa mûûtû wa mûhîa (I will make sorghum porridge)
Ûmûthî ngûcoka hinge mûrango (Today then I will shut the door)
Ndî na karamu (I have a pen)
Wî na tûramû (You have pens)
E na ngîrathi yakwa (He/she has my glass)
Me na ngîrathi ciakwa (They have my glasses)
Twî na mwarimû ûngî (We have another teacher)
Mwî na thîna (You all have problems)

entries.english: Verb 'Hûra' - multiple meanings: beat, iron, wash, start, call
examples: Hûra nguo bathi (Iron clothes)
Hûra nguo (Wash clothes)
Hûra ngarî mwaki (Start a car)
Hûra thimû (Make a phone call)
Hûrîra thimû (Call me by phone)
Hûrîra nguo bathi (Iron clothes for me)
Wîhûrîre nguo bathi (Iron clothes for yourself)
Nî ngwîhûrîra bathi (I will iron for myself)

entries.english: Present location - to be here (all persons)
To push (we form in all tenses)

examples.english: Today I bathed with cold water
Yesterday I bathed with cold water
Day before yesterday I bathed with cold water

grammatical_info.construction: subject prefix + past marker + na + object

entries.kikuyu: Ciũria na macokio ma ihinda rĩrathira

examples.notes: Affirmative past perfect with location and time

constructions: Nī + subject prefix + verb stem + ite + kabere

entries.kikuyu: Kugarũra mĩario ya andũ arĩa matiarĩa na arĩa marĩa

entries.english: Location expressions: now vs earlier today
entries.kikuyu: Kũrĩa andũ marĩ: rĩu na tene ũmũthĩ

examples.english: We are here and we're eating meat
We were here earlier and we ate meat

entries.kikuyu: Ciũria cia menyerero ya nyamũ cia gĩthaka

examples.english: Have you ever seen an ostrich?
Have they ever seen a rhino?
Have you all ever seen a lion?

grammatical_info.pattern: Nĩ + subject marker + rĩ + verb stem

entries.english: To speak (aria) - all persons habitual form
First person present habitual with pronouns

grammatical_info.notes: The gũ-/kũ- alternation follows Dahl's Law where kũ- is used before stems starting with certain consonants

entries.kikuyu: Past Tense - Two Types (Moments Ago & Early Today)

grammatical_info.notes: Kikuyu distinguishes between actions that happened moments ago versus actions that happened earlier today

examples.english: If I knew, what would I do?
If we knew, what would we do?
If you knew, what would you do?
If you all knew, what would you all do?
If he/she knew, what would he/she do?
If they knew, what would they do?

grammatical_info.notes: The conditional marker '-ngĩ-' is used twice in conditional sentences: once with the condition verb and once with the result verb

entries.english: 1st Person Future Tense - Later Today (with Dahl's Law)
entries.kikuyu: 1st Person Future Tense - Later Today (with Dahl's Law)

grammatical_info.notes: This tense shows Dahl's Law in action, where gũ- changes to kũ- before certain consonants to avoid similar sounds in succession

grammatical_info.notes: This entry showcases various sound and feeling verbs in Kikuyu with past and future conjugations

examples.english: If you read/learn, would you become sharp/clever?
examples.notes: 2nd person singular conditional with result question

examples.english: If I read/learn I would become sharp/clever
examples.notes: 1st person singular conditional with result statement

examples.english: If we read/learn we would become sharp
examples.notes: 1st person plural conditional with result statement

examples.english: If they read/learn they would become sharp
examples.notes: 3rd person plural conditional with result statement

grammatical_info.notes: The 'no' connector is used between the condition and result clauses in this type of conditional construction
The progressive marker -ra- is used to indicate ongoing action in the present
The progressive marker -ra- is used to indicate ongoing action in the present. The assertive marker 'Nĩĩ' is used at the beginning of all 1st and 2nd person forms.

entries.context: Essential verb for literacy and education
entries.cultural_notes: Writing became important in Kikuyu culture with formal education and literacy programs

examples.english: I want to write a letter

entries.cultural_notes: One of the most frequently used verbs in daily conversation

entries.context: Expressing desire or preference (same root as 'go')
entries.cultural_notes: This verb can mean both 'want' and 'like', showing the connection between desire and movement in Kikuyu thinking
Essential verb for modern economic life and traditional trading

examples.english: I will buy vegetables at the market

entries.context: Physical action of grasping or catching
entries.cultural_notes: Important verb for physical activities, hunting, and handling objects

entries.context: Mental process of thinking or contemplating
entries.cultural_notes: Thinking and wisdom are highly valued in Kikuyu culture, with many proverbs about the importance of thought before action

examples.kikuyu: Nĩhithaga atĩ ũndũ ũyũ nĩ wega

entries.context: Modal verb expressing ability or possibility
entries.cultural_notes: Important auxiliary verb for expressing capability and potential
Respectful communication is central to Kikuyu culture. The verb 'hoya' implies polite asking rather than demanding
Learning is highly valued in Kikuyu culture, traditionally through storytelling, observation, and apprenticeship
This verb encompasses both physical hearing and emotional feeling, reflecting the Kikuyu understanding of the connection between senses and emotions

entries.context: General action verb for doing or making
entries.cultural_notes: One of the most versatile and frequently used verbs in Kikuyu, applicable to many activities and creation processes
Trying and perseverance are valued in Kikuyu culture, with many proverbs about the importance of effort

entries.context: Digging soil for farming or construction
entries.cultural_notes: Fundamental agricultural verb in Kikuyu farming culture. Digging is associated with preparation, hard work, and providing for the family
